awd_titl_txt: Neutrino-less Double-Beta Decay with CUORE and the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant partially supports neutrino research at the University of South Carolina (USC).  The group studies the properties of the neutrino, the most prolific particle in the universe, about which much is still unknown. The primary effort is the search for the hypothesized, but not yet discovered, nuclear-radioactive decay called zero-neutrino double-beta decay. The existence of such a radioactive decay mode has important consequences. Its existence requires that neutrinos have mass, and that they are their own anti-particles. Most importantly, this process would require the violation of an important fundamental conservation law of elementary particle physics.  The USC group has leadership roles in two of the leading experiments in this field: the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR, in the Sanford Underground Research Facility in South Dakota, and the Cryogenic Underground Observatory (CUORE) in the Laboratori Nazionali del Gran Sasso (LNGS) in Italy.  The spin-off technology from the required radiopurity of materials for the ultra-low background detectors has transitioned directly into Homeland Security.   Four past USC PhD students from the program hold important positions in Homeland Security, at the Pacific Northwest and Savannah River National Laboratories. 


CUORE, nearing completion in the LNGS, is an array of 988 tellurium oxide single-crystal bolometers that operate at ~8-10 mK to search for the zero-neutrino decay of tellurium-130 (Te-130); the detector will contain 200-kg of Te-130. The predicted half-life sensitivity is ~10^(26) years, to reach into the inverted hierarchy neutrino-mass region. USC leads part of the R&D to determine the feasibility and cost of enriching CUORE to 93% in Te-130 from 33.4%, and equipping the bolometers with Cherenkov-light detectors to discriminate against alpha-particle background. These upgrades are designed to reach the sensitivity required to cover the inverted neutrino mass hierarchy. USC leads the CUORE data analysis to search for zero-neutrino double-beta decay of Te-130 to the first excited 0+ state in xenon-130, by detecting the coincidence events from the two electrons and cascade gamma rays. This technique achieved zero-background in the prototype experiment, CUORICINO. Finally, the USC group was responsible for the production of the CUORE front-end electronics, and will participate in its installation, commissioning and maintenance.

por.por_cntn:
This project primarily supported the study of important properties of the elementary particle, the neutrino. Neutrinos are the most prolific particles in the universe except for photons, which are massless. One important question to be answered is: what is the absolute mass of neutrinos?  Another is: are neutrinos their own anti-particles? Clear answers to both of these questions would make major impacts in cosmology, astrophysics, and elementary physics. The only practical way to experimentally address these questions is to search for an exotic decay of a nucleus called neutrino-less double-beta decay. In the less exotic case of ordinary double-beta decay, an unstable nucleus can decay to a daughter by emitting two electrons and two neutrinos, thereby increasing its atomic number by two. This process, though rare, has been observed in more than a dozen cases. This radioactive decay mode conserves lepton number if the electrons are each assigned lepton number plus one, and the neutrinos emitted are anti-neutrinos each assigned lepton number minus one. This conservation law is found to be conserved in all known reactions where the light particles called leptons (electrons and neutrinos in this case) are involved. The direct observation of neutrino-less double-beta decay would be the first known violation of this important conservation law, and would be an important contribution to elementary-particle physics. The measurement of the rate of this exotic decay would allow the determination of the absolute mass of neutrinos when combined with data from accelerator experiments. This knowledge would be crucial input to current cosmology models of the evolution of the universe.

            The grant in question supported three faculty members, three PhD students, and one post-doctoral research associate while they contributed to the design, construction and operation of both the MAJORANA and CUORE neutrino-less double-beta decay experiments over a period of five years. The PI was a level-2 manager of both experiments during their construction and commissioning, while the group later contributed to the data collection, analysis, interpretation and publication of the results. While no direct observation or discovery was made, tighter constraints were placed on the lower limits of the half- lives and implied effective masses of electron neutrinos. In addition, the results of both experiments have led the way to the design of two next-generation experiments, LEGEND and CUPID, which are designed to have discovery sensitivities about one hundred times better than those of MAJORANA and CUORE. The PI and his team are contributing to the planning and design of these two future experiments. The grant also partially funded a new material science facility at the University of South Carolina, which will be dedicated to directly support the above named next-generation experiments.
